p.s: Description of Pasteurella trehalosi sp. nov.
Pasteurella trehalosi (tre. hal.os'i. M.L. gen. n. trehalosi, pertaining to trehalosum [trehalose])

P. haemolytica group T, which was distinguished by Smith (40, 41) from P. haemolytica sensu stricto (which is group A, to which type strain NCTC 9380 of P. haemolytica belongs); phenon 9 of Sneath and Stevens (46); P. haemolytica T of Kilian and Frederiksen (21); P. haemolytica biovar T of Carter (11).
Cells are small nonmotile rods and coccobacilli.
Growth is aerobic and facultatively anaerobic, mesophilic.

Surface colonies grown aerobically on sheep blood agar are round, greyish, semitransparent, and about 2.5 mm in diameter after 48 h at 37Â°C; they usually have a pronounced zone of hemolysis (often double) and occasionally produce some greening of the erythrocytes.

Notable for giving a weak or negative reaction for catalase and a negative reaction for urease, in producing acid from sorbitol and trehalose but not from galactoce, and for often showing delayed fermentation in Hugh-Leifson (17) medium (46).

This organism is distinguished from P. haemolytica sensu stricto by fermenting trehalose but not L-(+)-arabhose and usually not galactose or D-(+)-xylose and by being relatively more resistant to penicillin (2, 11).
Other properties are shown in Table 2.
Associated with septicemia in older lambs, unlike P. haemolytica sensu stricto, which is associated with pneumonia in cattle and sheep and septicemia in newborn lambs (11, 40, 41).

This organism is phenotypically similar to P. haemolytica, P. pneumotropica, Pasteurella gallinarum, and P. multocida (46) and shows low DNA-DNA pairing values (15 to 35%) to P. haemolytica, P. gallinarum, P. ureae, and P. multocida (3, 28, 35).
P. trehalosi exhibits a level of pairing of about 62% to Pasteurella testudinis (26, 28).
The G+C content of the DNA of one strain of biovar T, serovar 3/T15 (9), strain NCTC 10624, is 42.6 mol% (Tm method) (26, 28).
The type strain is strain NCTC 10370 (= S11O = ATCC 29703 = A92 = serovar 3/T15) (9, 46).
